title: Glimpse inside recently sold Playboy Mansion reveals different story to busty bunnies and hedonistic parties
text:

A unique photo series has revealed a different look inside the Playboy Mansion, away from the glitz and glamorous of bunnies and wild parties that made it famous. 
Jeff Minton has captured the famous mansion, located in Los Angeles' Holmby Hills, before its wild party days end after being sold for $100 million (£80 million). 
Playboy founder Hugh Hefner , now in his 90s, sold the historic home last year but has struck a deal that allows him to live their until he dies. 
Minton said he shot almost 6,000 photographs during his visit, starting with Hugh’s monkeys before exploring all 22 rooms and their decorations. One of Hef's monkeys with a woman at the mansion (Photo: Jeff Minton) A cardboard cutout of Hugh Hefner is among the decorations (Photo: Jeff Minton) A bird at the Los Angeles property (Photo: Jeff Minton) Artwork in one of the mansion's rooms (Photo: Jeff Minton) Animal seat cover prints (Photo: Jeff Minton) A model with one of the mansion's birds (Photo: Jeff Minton) 
Minton has captured a very retro-looking property, decorated at times in bright colours with old-fashioned fittings. 
There some shorts with a hint of female fun we might have expected - but mostly the shots examine the property's less famous inhabitants and features. 
“My goal became to create the most comprehensive look at the mansion ever, down to the smallest details,” Minton told It's Nice That . Read More Animals - both real and in art - are a common feature at the property (Photo: Jeff Minton) Lipstick marks left on a sculpture at the mansion (Photo: Jeff Minton) A puzzle at the mansion (Photo: Jeff Minton) An exotic bird roams the grounds of the Los Angeles pad (Photo: Jeff Minton) A stylish staircase (Photo: Jeff Minton) Bed coverings in the mansion (Photo: Jeff Minton) An old-style telephone (Photo: Jeff Minton) A risque puzzle (Photo: Jeff Minton) Another puzzle (Photo: Jeff Minton) 
“I soon realised these details were the most interesting to me. 
"The things people would overlook as they wander the grounds.” 
“The property is nearly 100 years old and it shows its wear in many ways. I guess I just wanted to celebrate the mansion in all of its tattered glory.” Read More The cardboard cutout moves around the mansion (Photo: Jeff Minton) The pool, with a visitor (Photo: Jeff Minton) The monkey enjoys the attention from the bunny (Photo: Jeff Minton) Hugh's famous pyjamas (Photo: Jeff Minton) The mansion's pool (Photo: Jeff Minton) A Playboy Bunny cut-out gives instructions to guests (Photo: Jeff Minton) 
But Jeff still seems surprised to have been let in with his camera. 
“I’m not exactly sure how I got permission to shoot the house, but I believe Hugh Hefner saw a photograph of a monkey I took for New York Magazine and thought it would be great for me to come shoot some of his animals," he adds. 
"He actually has so many wild animals that he has a zookeeper on staff, as well as a pet cemetery. A bunny on a bed (Photo: Jeff Minton) A bunny costume decoration left on the ground (Photo: Jeff Minton) A bunny in the pool (Photo: Jeff Minton) A plant in the property (Photo: Jeff Minton) 
“The project expanded from there and I ended up spending a week at the mansion, shooting everything.” 
The mansion has been Hefner's home since 1971 when he paid $1 million for the property. 
It has featured in several films and television series, including Girls of The Playboy Mansion. One of the notorious parties at the mansion over the years (Photo: Camera Press Digital) Some bunnies who frequent the mansion (Photo: EMPICS Entertainment) Hef with one of his women (Photo: Camera Press Digital) 
The property has also been home to Hefner's assortment of bunny girlfriends. 
The new buyer is Daren Metropoulos, a billionaire private equity banker.
